message.content: This question requires some knowledge about the effect of wind on a hang-glider. When a hang-glider is soaring and runs into gales (strong, gusty winds) head-on, the gales will slow down the glider. Strong headwinds create resistance and make it more difficult for the hang-glider to maintain its speed and altitude. Option (A) is incorrect because the gales would not cause the hang-glider to sink, unless there are extreme wind conditions. Option (B) is also incorrect because the gales would not speed up the glider. Option (C) is incorrect because crashing the glider would require more than just encountering strong headwinds.

This question requires knowledge about the impact of wind on a hang-glider. When a hang-glider runs into gales head-on, the gales slow the glider down. This is because the strong headwinds create resistance against the forward motion of the glider, causing it to slow down. Option (A) is incorrect because the gales do not cause the glider to sink. Option (B) is incorrect because the gales do not speed up the glider. Option (C) is incorrect because the gales do not crash the glider.

This question requires basic knowledge about the effect of head-on winds on a hang-glider. When a hang-glider is soaring and it runs into gales head-on, the gales will slow down the glider. Head-on winds create resistance and make it more difficult for the glider to maintain its speed and altitude. Option (A) is incorrect because the gales would not cause the glider to sink unless its force is strong enough to overcome the lift generated by the glider. Option (B) is incorrect because the gales would not speed up the glider. Option (C) is incorrect because crashing would be a result of losing control, not a direct effect of the gales.

This question requires some understanding of the forces and dynamics involved in hang-gliding. When a hang-glider runs into gales head-on, it experiences a resistance force that slows it down. Option (A) is incorrect because the gales would not cause the glider to sink unless combined with other factors. Option (B) is incorrect because the gales would not speed up the glider. Option (C) is incorrect because the gales alone would not cause the glider to crash. The correct answer is (D) because the gales would slow down the glider.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the effects of wind on a hang-glider. When a hang-glider is soaring and runs into gales head-on, the gales will slow the glider down. This is because the strong headwind creates resistance against the forward motion of the glider. Option (A) is incorrect because the gales do not cause the glider to sink. Option (B) is incorrect because the gales do not speed up the glider. Option (C) is incorrect because the gales do not crash the glider.

This question requires basic knowledge about the effects of headwinds on a hang-glider. When a hang-glider is soaring and encounters headwinds (gales coming from the front), it slows the glider down. The headwinds create resistance and counteract the forward motion of the glider, causing it to slow down. Option (A) is incorrect because the headwinds do not cause the glider to sink. Option (B) is incorrect because the headwinds do not speed up the glider. Option (C) is incorrect because crashing would imply a collision, which is not mentioned in the question.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the effects of wind on a hang-glider. When a hang-glider is soaring and runs into head-on gales (strong winds from the front), it slows down the glider. The force of the wind pushing against the glider creates resistance and makes it harder for the glider to maintain its speed. Option (A) is incorrect because sinking would involve downward motion, which is not mentioned in the question. Option (B) is incorrect because the gales would not speed up the glider, but rather slow it down. Option (C) is incorrect because crashing would involve a loss of control or collision, which is not mentioned in the question.

This question requires an understanding of the principles of aerodynamics and how wind affects a flying object. When a hang-glider runs into gales head-on, the gales will slow the glider down. This is because the strong headwind will create resistance against the glider's forward motion, causing it to slow down. Option (A) is incorrect because sinking refers to the glider descending, not slowing down. Option (B) is incorrect because speeding up in this scenario would require a tailwind, not a headwind. Option (C) is incorrect because crashing is a result of loss of control or impact, not the effect of head-on wind.

Option (A) is incorrect because the wind would not sink the glider. Option (B) is incorrect because the wind resistance would make it harder for the glider to move forward and gain speed. Option (C) is incorrect because crashing the glider would depend on various factors other than just the head-on wind.

Option (A) is incorrect because sinking implies a downward motion, which is not necessarily the case in this scenario.
